p: The genome of HEV is a single-stranded, positive-sense, RNA molecule of approximately 7.2 kb in size [ 3, 4, 27]. The genome consists of three open reading frames (ORFs), a 5′ non-coding region (NCR), and a 3′ NCR [ 10]. ORF1 encodes non-structural proteins with conserved domains functioning as a methyltransferase, helicase, RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp), and a papain-like cysteine protease [ 20, 28]. In addition, a hypervariable region (HVR) within ORF1 may play a role in viral pathogenesis despite being shown to have no influence on viral infectivity [ 29]. ORF2 encodes the immunogenic capsid protein, which interacts with 3′ viral genomic RNA for encapsidation and contains an endoplasmic reticulum signal peptide and 3′ N-glycosylation sites [ 30, 31]. ORF3 encodes a small phosphoprotein with incompletely understood functions; however, the association with cytoskeleton and its necessity for in vivo viral infection in rhesus macaques suggests that ORF3 plays a role in viral replication and assembly [ 20, 32, 33].
